articles.headline: U.S. Supports New Nuclear Reactors in Georgia
articles.snippet: The president announced approval of an $8.3 billion loan guarantee for two reactors in Georgia, which would be the first nuclear plants built in the United States since the 1970s.
articles.abstract: The president announced approval of an $8.3 billion loan guarantee for two reactors in Georgia, which would be the first nuclear plants built in the United States since the 1970s.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama, speaking to an enthusiastic audience of union officials in Lanham, Md., on Tuesday, underscored his embrace of nuclear power as a clean energy source, announcing that the Energy Department had approved financial help for the construction of two nuclear reactors in Georgia.

articles.headline: Energy Company Mergers Are Expected to Rise
articles.snippet: Energy companies are focused on buying fast-growing small companies, or on acquisitions that expand reserves.
articles.abstract: Energy companies are focused on buying fast-growing small companies, or on acquisitions that expand reserves.
articles.lead_paragraph: Energy companies are on the prowl again.

articles.headline: Judging Stimulus by Job Data Reveals Success
articles.snippet: If, last year, Congress had passed a stimulus bill that really worked, what would the economy look like today? Well, almost exactly as it does now.
articles.abstract: If, last year, Congress had passed a stimulus bill that really worked, what would the economy look like today? Well, almost exactly as it does now.

articles.headline: Elders of Wall St. Favor More Regulation
articles.snippet: George Soros, Nicholas F. Brady, John S. Reed and others favor the so-called Volcker Rule to restrict bank activities.
articles.abstract: George Soros, Nicholas F. Brady, John S. Reed and others favor the so-called Volcker Rule to restrict bank activities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Put aside for a moment the populist pressure to regulate banking and trading. Ask the elder statesmen of these industries  giants like George Soros, Nicholas F. Brady, John S. Reed, William H. Donaldson and John C. Bogle  where they stand on regulation, and they will bowl you over with their populism.

articles.headline: Slow Trip Across Sea Aids Profit and Environment
articles.snippet: Halving a container ship’s top speed cuts fuel consumption and emissions of greenhouse gases.
articles.abstract: Halving a container ship’s top speed cuts fuel consumption and emissions of greenhouse gases.
articles.lead_paragraph: It took more than a month for the container ship Ebba Maersk to steam from Germany to Guangdong, China, where it unloaded cargo on a recent Friday  a week longer than it did two years ago.

articles.headline: Party Gridlock in Washington Feeds Fear of a Debt Crisis
articles.snippet: A polarized political system seems unable to solve problems that involve trust, tough choices and little short-term gain.
articles.abstract: A polarized political system seems unable to solve problems that involve trust, tough choices and little short-term gain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator Evan Bayh’s comments this week about a dysfunctional Congress reflected a complaint being directed at Washington with increasing frequency, and there is broad agreement among critics about Exhibit A: The unwillingness of the two parties to compromise to control a national debt that is rising to dangerous heights.

articles.headline: Taliban Arrest May Be Crucial for Pakistanis
articles.snippet: Pakistan has eliminated a key opponent and ensured a place for itself in negotiating the end of the Afghan war.
articles.abstract: Pakistan has eliminated a key opponent and ensured a place for itself in negotiating the end of the Afghan war.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s arrest of the top Taliban military commander may be a tactical victory for the United States, but it is also potentially a strategic coup for Pakistan, officials and analysts here and in Afghanistan said.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Souad Mekhennet

articles.headline: With Big Takeover Bid, Simon Aims to Control 30% of U.S. Malls
articles.snippet: General Growth Properties, the bankrupt mall company, rebuffed the unsolicited $10 billion offer from the Simon Property Group, calling the bid too low.
articles.abstract: General Growth Properties, the bankrupt mall company, rebuffed the unsolicited $10 billion offer from the Simon Property Group, calling the bid too low.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months of speculation, the Simon Property Group on Tuesday finally made an unsolicited $10 billion offer for General Growth Properties, its bankrupt rival. But General Growth quickly rebuffed the approach, calling the bid too low.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Stimulus Jobs on State’s Bill in Mississippi
articles.snippet: Mississippi is one of 21 states using stimulus money to pay the salaries of private employers’ new hires.
articles.abstract: Mississippi is one of 21 states using stimulus money to pay the salaries of private employers’ new hires.
articles.lead_paragraph: HATTIESBURG, Miss.  Scott Phillips had to close his small plumbing company after the housing bubble burst and his business dried up. Roshonda Bolton lost her job when the garment and uniform factory where she had worked for 16 years shut down last August.
